Revert "Further reduce the maximum repeat count when fuzzing."

This reverts commit 5603c16a2d0b1a4f489df6e66ae3a27198d8d75a, which was
intended to limit repetitions of Unicode character classes in regular
expressions generated by the RE2 fuzzer, but turned out to affect
human-written regular expressions.

Change-Id: I551739452060dc71409bae589c70f4902e9a11b7
Reviewed-on: https://code-review.googlesource.com/18590
Reviewed-by: Paul Wankadia <junyer@google.com>

issue_comments.body: `?` is the metacharacter that means zero or one, so `url` used as a regular expression will not match itself. Either pass `RE2::QuoteMeta(url)` instead of `url` or declare an `RE2::Options` object, call `set_literal(true)` on it, construct an `RE2` object with it and pass **that** instead of `url`.
Sorry, RE2 supports UTF-8 and Latin-1 only.
Fixed by e69f55cbdaa45e9fe5f8e4354146b3126ded2c11.
Fixed by e69f55cbdaa45e9fe5f8e4354146b3126ded2c11.
The `i`, `m` and `s` modifiers have been supported (and documented) for a long time. The `x` modifier could be supported someday, I guess, but it's arguably unnecessary in C++.
Considering the detailed comments in the test code, I'm wondering whether this could have been due to a compiler bug. What compiler version were you using?
Does `__*3re211StringPieceE` work better?

Since 59d96121fea1bab268b5969b2a7344f0bdfdaeb0, `libre2.symbols.darwin` lists `__ZN3re211FilteredRE2*` and `__ZNK3re211FilteredRE210AllMatches*`, but not `__ZNK3re211FilteredRE2*`. Does it need to be readded?

If you just want the submatches as strings, I'd suggest using `RE2::Match()` instead of fiddling around with `RE2::Arg` objects.

Please send mail to re2-dev@googlegroups.com if you have further questions. There are many people subscribed to the mailing list, but very few who triage the GitHub issues.
Please see https://github.com/google/re2/wiki/Contribute for instructions regarding contributions. Thanks!
Please see https://github.com/google/re2/wiki/Contribute for instructions regarding contributions. Thanks!
Please see https://github.com/google/re2/wiki/Contribute for instructions regarding contributions. Thanks!
Please see https://github.com/google/re2/wiki/Contribute for instructions regarding contributions. Thanks!
D'oh! What's in `obj/so/test/filtered_re2_test.log`?
It looks like that documentation link is supposed to take you to the RE2 syntax wiki page. Judging from https://github.com/golang/go/issues/10471, it will do so as of the next Go release. :)
We use the wiki (https://github.com/google/re2/wiki) for our documentation. :)
Thanks for the report! I'd been meaning to tidy this up for some time.
I've just committed 800c90aa250d56701444cf2f91785513dbd1641d to test the static library as well. I'll see whether I can reproduce the issue now.

Confirmed on Ubuntu 14.10.

The output of `strace(1)` indicates that something is sleeping on a futex and blocking indefinitely:

```
…
brk(0xdef200)                           = 0xdef200
brk(0xdf0000)                           = 0xdf0000
futex(0x7bc4a0, FUTEX_WAKE_PRIVATE, 1)  = 0
access("/etc/ld.so.nohwcap", F_OK)      = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
futex(0xdd02f4, FUTEX_WAIT_PRIVATE, 0, NULL
```

```
…
(gdb) bt
#0  pthread_rwlock_wrlock () at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/pthread_rwlock_wrlock.S:85
#1  0x0000000000445bce in Lock (this=0x7da2e8) at ./util/mutex.h:111
#2  MutexLock (mu=0x7da2e8, this=<synthetic pointer>) at ./util/mutex.h:151
#3  RunStateOnByteUnlocked (c=<optimised out>, state=0x7db370, this=0x7da2d0) at re2/dfa.cc:962
…
```

I have no idea what changed to break this. :)

commit_comments.body: D'oh! Fixed in a632405605966427baf5c059d7653c66353b52e6. Thanks for the report!
@DThiebaud Thanks! And if you pull d9cc8e580e4ff2b38e7417b07f3d0215787a4619, please feel free to try using CMake to generate an MSVC project. :)

Our PCRE wrapper code has not seen much love over the years, but it should build even without PCRE present. (You have to build with `-DUSEPCRE` to make it actually use PCRE.) Joe Atzinger has reported success in the past, so there might be only a few wrinkles left to iron out. Please file bugs for any problems that you find!
Could you please paste the latest errors? The file names and line numbers will hopefully be helpful. Thanks!

commits.message:
[Bazel] Do not set -pthread etc. on Windows

Doing the same thing as Tensorflow, Protobuf and GoogleTest.

-
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/BUILD#L108
- https://github.com/google/protobuf/blob/master/BUILD#L32
- https://github.com/google/googletest/blob/master/BUILD.bazel#L39

Change-Id: Ic6efc70a3021c00bb8a2200766a98266de747f26
Reviewed-on: https://code-review.googlesource.com/21970
Reviewed-by: Paul Wankadia <junyer@google.com>

Avoid warning in CMake when using re2 as a subproject

Change-Id: Iebd37f2367a29db386a20a7686b93c54c3b2c7cd
Reviewed-on: https://code-review.googlesource.com/18071
Reviewed-by: Paul Wankadia <junyer@google.com>

issue_comments.body:
Perl does not interpret \x in regexp replacement strings:

```
g% perl -e '$x="abc"; $y="<\\x62>"; $x =~ s/$x/$y/; print "$x\n";'
<\x62>
g%
```

It does interpret \x in ordinary strings but so does RE2's host language, C.
No ideas here.
Any fix for this yet? I am experiencing the same issue on Yosemite.
I had the same problem.  It was fixed by adding __ZNK3re211FilteredRE2\* to libre2.symbols.darwin, as mentioned in the thread https://code.google.com/p/re2/issues/detail?id=59

+1

For now one can use https://github.com/google/re2/blob/master/doc/syntax.txt instead.

The same dead link is used in BigQuery's docs too:
https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/query-reference#regularexpressionfunctions
(I'm assuming it's OK to send a fix directly.)

Junyer, looks like re-adding __ZNK3re211FilteredRE2 lets me run `make testinstall` successfully, but then breaks `make test`

`obj/so/test/filtered_re2_test     FAIL;`

Why did you closed the ticket?  The problem still stands.  It's not easy to find the documentation from the README which just refers to the GitHub page.  A simple fix would be to change the link in the README to point to the wiki.

commit_comments.body:
This breaks OS X (tested on Yosemite) throwing error:

make testinstall
cp testinstall.cc obj
(cd obj && c++ -I/usr/local/include -L/usr/local/lib testinstall.cc -lre2 -pthread -static -o testinstall)
ld: library not found for -lcrt0.o
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
make: **\* [testinstall] Error 1

My research tells me OS X doesn't like static linking :-P.....  may want to condition it as exclusion in Darwin....

I commented it out and it test ok:

make testinstall
cp testinstall.cc obj
# (cd obj && c++ -I/usr/local/include -L/usr/local/lib testinstall.cc -lre2 -pthread -static -o testinstall)
# obj/testinstall

(cd obj && c++ -I/usr/local/include -L/usr/local/lib testinstall.cc -lre2 -pthread -o testinstall)
LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/local/lib obj/testinstall
PASS
This looks good to me. I will test it.
When I tried to build with CMAKE, I couldn't build the tests. pcre.cc had dozens of compile errors. I suspect I'm doing something wrong. This was with MSVC 2015. I'll play with this more later.

This still gets similar compile errors as before. In threadwin.cc, if I change:
# include "util/util.h"
# include "util/thread.h"

 to 
# include "util/thread.h"
# include "util/util.h"

then it compiles cleanly. It's as if the include of util.h prevents the include of windows.h in thread.h from working.. I don't know why this happens, but it happens on my PC>
threadwin.cc compiles cleanly for me now.
This change broke build with Bazel on sandboxed environment, see http://ci.bazel.io/job/re2/BAZEL_VERSION=HEAD,PLATFORM_NAME=linux-x86_64/115/console
would be cool to see an example image produced by this gnuplot support
